Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 45292-001 
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
December 2011 
 
 
 
Strengthening Evaluation of Poverty Reduction 
Innovations 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
DMC  –  developing member country 
IED  –  Independent Evaluation Department 
RCT  –  randomized control trial  
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  Targeted intervention—MDG 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Multisector (economic and public affairs management, 
microfinance, small and medium-sized enterprise, finance and 
leasing, insurance and contractual savings, social protection) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (widening access to markets and economic 
opportunities), social development (other vulnerable groups), 
gender equity (gender equity in economic opportunities), capacity 
development (client relations, network, and partnership 
development) 
Location impact  –  Rural (medium), urban (low), national (medium), regional (medium)  
     
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Directors General  K. Gerhaeusser, East Asia Department (EARD) 
V. Thomas, Independent Evaluation Department (IED) 
Directors  H. Hettige, Independent Evaluation Division 2, IED 
Y. Qian, Public Management, Financial Sector, and Regional 
Cooperation Division, EARD 
   
Co-team leaders  B. Wilkinson, Principal Financial Sector Specialist, EARD 
B. Nguyen, Senior Evaluation Specialist, IED 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) overarching goal is an Asia and Pacific region 
free of poverty. ADB’s Strategy 2020 commits the institution to monitoring, evaluating, and 
reporting on its activities using new results frameworks focused on ensuring management for 
development results.1 Strategy 2020 and the new financial sector operations plan firmly commit 
ADB to stronger, broader engagement in financial inclusion and in ongoing improvements in 
poverty reduction methods.2 The intersection of these commitments is the use of the most 
modern and effective tools for evaluating poverty and financial inclusion projects. A key method 
to ensure results is to strengthen the understanding of developing member country (DMC) 
policymakers, researchers, and implementing agencies about new evaluation methods and use 
of results to enhance policy and practice.  
 
2.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  improve  DMC  ability  to  measure,  evaluate,  and 
replicate  access  to  finance  and  other  related  poverty  reduction  efforts  by  increasing 
understanding  and  application  of  randomized  control  trials  and  other  modern  evaluation 
techniques. The TA will achieve this result in three ways. First, it will introduce new evaluation 
techniques to DMC officials and academics in a short, practical training course, with information 
on how to apply the results to improve policy and practice. Second, the TA will run a 3-day 
international conference, where practitioners and researchers from around the globe will present 
the latest evaluation results of projects in financial access and poverty reduction to policymakers. 
Gender  impact  will  be  an  essential  aspect  of  the  presentations.  Finally,  an  evaluation 
implementation grants program will facilitate evaluation of benefits and capacity building for 
DMCs. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  ADB has continued its efforts to enhance evaluation of its own projects, to help learn and 
demonstrate  results,  and  to  use  the  results  and  new  technologies  of  other  evaluators  to 
enhance learning and good practice.4 However, it needs to help expand DMC knowledge of 
newer methods used in evaluation worldwide. This is particularly important when new evaluation 
tools are used on innovative projects in financial inclusion and poverty reduction.  
 
4.  Refined  evaluation methods  help  facilitate  better  project  evaluation  and  subsequent 
project improvements.5 In particular, improved evaluation methods have enabled more rigor in 
determining  the  impact  of  projects  on  affected  households.  One  of  the  more  important 
improvements in evaluation methodology is the introduction of randomized control trials (RCTs) 
                                                
1  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
2  ADB. 2011.  Financial Sector Operations Plan. Manila. “ADB will support DMCs’ efforts to enhance the financial 
access for the traditionally underserved such as poor households, vulnerable groups (e.g., women, minorities), and 
small and medium-sized enterprises to promote inclusive economic growth…” (p. 13) 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 30 November 2011. 
4  ADB. 2009. Capacity Development in Results-Based Monitoring and Evaluation for Countries under the Asian 
Development Bank's Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program (financed by the People's Republic of 
China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund). Manila (TA 7348-REG); and ADB. 2007. Technical 
Assistance for Capacity Development for Monitoring and Evaluation. Manila (TA 6410-REG). Participants from 
Bhutan, the People’s Republic of China, Indonesia, Kazakhstan, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Philippines, 
Tajikistan, and Viet Nam have participated in training on general evaluation and wish to engage in further capacity 
building. The PRC has specifically asked about this TA and expressed interest, by email, through the Chinese 
Academy of Sciences. All ADB DMCs will be invited; participation is on a first-come, first-served basis pending 
collaboration arrangements by other development partners for a larger group.  
5   ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance for Implementing Impact Evaluation at ADB (TA 7680-REG) Manila.

2   
to fieldwork in microfinance, small and medium-sized enterprises, and other areas. RCTs are 
derived from methods used for drug testing. They measure an intervention’s effect by randomly 
assigning individuals (or groups of individuals) to an intervention group or a control group. RCTs 
enable researchers to accurately assess whether the intervention itself, as opposed to other 
factors, caused the observed outcomes. RCTs may not be feasible in cases where the impact 
cannot be effectively randomized. In such cases, rigorous comparative studies are a better 
method.  
 
5.  Innovations are emerging from new work in RCTs, especially in access to finance, 
resource transfers such as community-driven development and conditional cash transfers, and 
work with the ultra-poor. Almost all of the new evaluation work considers sex-disaggregated 
data, enabling better determination of distinct effects on women and men. Recently released 
books, such as Poor Economics: A Radical Rethinking of the Way to Fight Global Poverty6 and 
More Than Good Intentions: How a New Economics Is Helping to Solve Global Poverty7 provide 
intriguing insights on poverty reduction efforts based on results of recent evaluations. More 
knowledge  is  continuing  to  emerge.  For  example,  the  RCT  of  Progresa  in  Mexico,  an 
experiment  on  conditional  cash  transfers to families  dependent  on their  children  attending 
school  and  clinics,  shows  the  power  of  evaluation  results  on  policy.  However,  significant 
critiques of RCT methodology and comments on alternatives are important to consider.8 
 
6.  In October 2010, the first Microfinance Impact and Innovation Conference took place in 
New  York  City.  It  was  a  unique  forum  to  communicate  recently  accumulated  evaluation 
knowledge and generation of innovations in product design and research.9 Academics and 
implementers  presented  evaluation  results  on  RCTs  of  new  products  and  services  in 
microfinance, small and medium-sized enterprise development, social development, education, 
ultra-poor development, and other poverty reduction efforts. Much of the research was just 
finalized. The findings identified errors in traditional approaches and suggested some new ways 
of addressing poverty issues. Researchers also demonstrated ways of determining differential 
effects  of  a  single  change  on  people—by gender  or  age, for  example.  At  the  end  of the 
conference, researchers participated in a “marketplace” where they proposed ideas they would 
like to evaluate in the field, and development partners and country representatives expressed 
interest in engagement and funding. The participants strongly felt that replication of the event 
and expanding participation to include DMC policy makers would significantly increase its value. 
Other development partners, such as the Inter-American Development Bank, Citi Foundation, 
and the Islamic Development Bank found this process very valuable. They are consulting with 
ADB for collaboration arrangements, specifically to finance more DMC participants participating 
in the conference and to increase the grant funds available. 
 
                                                
6  A. Bannerjee and E. Duflos. 2011. Poor Economics: A Radical Rethinking of the Way to Fight Global Poverty. New 
York: Public Affairs Publishing. 
7  D. Karlan and J. Appel. 2011.  More Than Good Intentions: How a New Economics Is Helping to Solve Global 
Poverty. Boston: Dutton Adult Press. 
8  A. Deaton. 2010. Instruments, Randomization, and Learning About Development. Journal of Economic Literature. 
48 (June). p. 424–455 (P. Gertler reporting, p. 449). Following the evaluation over 30 countries have introduced 
conditional cash transfers. 
9  The event was hosted by the Financial Access Initiative, a consortium of development economists at three 
American academic institutions, New York University, Yale University, and Harvard University; Innovations for 
Poverty Action, a American-based nonprofit, which develops solutions to social problems and provided all technical 
setup, conference management, and proceedings; and the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab, a network of 
professors at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, which conducts research on poverty reduction. Moody’s, 
Deutsche Bank, and Global Call to Action against Poverty also contributed resources. Planned for 100, more than 
350 academics, implementers, and a few development partners and DMC officials attended the 3-day event.

3 
7.  DMC officials rarely have the opportunity to talk to field practitioners from other countries 
and continents to discuss the results of field innovations in financial inclusion and related 
poverty reduction. They never have the opportunity to see practitioners pairing with world-class 
academics to prove (or disprove) the results of their approaches in the field. The presentations 
at New York Conference enabled both development partners and DMC officials to learn about 
what people were trying elsewhere, and what had worked (or not) and why. They also heard 
how these results were assessed in terms of the differential impacts on men and women, and 
what could be done to improve the impact. As countries in Asia and the Pacific face a broad 
range of issues from the middle-income trap10 to fragile state risks, it is helpful for DMC officials 
to understand what innovations have been tried in other countries, what options are surfacing, 
and what else they can explore.  
 
8.  Bringing this information to the DMCs and encouraging the use of improved evaluation 
techniques in appropriate ways would bring substantial benefits. Providing training to key DMC 
officials and academics would enable them to understand and use new evaluation techniques 
more confidently. They would then more readily use evaluation results when determining policy 
and new initiatives for financial inclusion and poverty reduction projects. Learning about and 
discussing worldwide results of evaluations in a conference setting would help everyone learn 
how evaluations work and what they teach us. Innovations can also be shared. ADB could then 
facilitate pilots of evaluation techniques for interested DMCs to use in measuring the results of 
financial inclusion and related poverty reduction methods.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact of the TA will be more effective evaluation of financial inclusion and related 
poverty reduction projects in participating DMCs. The outcome will be increased understanding 
and application of sex-disaggregated randomized control trials and other modern evaluation 
tools, such as rigorous comparison, for poverty reduction innovations by participating DMC 
academics and officials. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The outputs are (i) a 3-day training course in impact evaluation techniques, (ii) a 3-day 
international conference sharing the latest evaluation results worldwide, and (iii) implementation 
of  competitively  awarded  innovation  evaluation  grants  for  DMCs.  Blending  training  and 
experience with resources to use the new knowledge immediately provides strong opportunities 
for  success.  Completion  of  the  evaluation  grants,  with  ongoing  consultations  involving  the 
trained officials, will reinforce lessons and engagement in the evaluation process. Gender is a 
critical issue, and thus will be integral to learning, presentations, and participation; the intention 
is that one-third of those targeted for all three outputs will be women. 
 
11.  The 3-day training course will be developed and delivered specifically for DMC policy 
makers and researchers. The participants will be surveyed well in advance of the course to 
determine understanding, interests, and particular responsibilities for financial inclusion and 
related poverty reduction. The course will be tailored to their specific practical needs and 
                                                
10 The middle-income trap can be defined as a transition point when a developing economy has reached middle- 
income levels using existing natural and human resources and traditional industrial growth. It is generally agreed 
that countries do not transition to high income unless they can move to service-led, highly innovative economies.

4   
requests, but be sufficiently general to have broader application. Recent experience of the 
Independent Evaluation Department (IED) in basic evaluation training for DMC officials will be 
taken  into  account.  The  3-day  training  will  occur  during  the  end  of  the  week  before  the 
international  conference,  to  allow  participants  to  engage  immediately  in  the  conference.  A 
survey will be conducted after the course to determine changes in knowledge and practice. The 
course will be videotaped and an e-learning course provided on the ADB website. 
 
12.  The  international  conference  will  incorporate  the  latest  findings  in  evaluation,  with 
conference dates tentatively set for 28–31 August 2012 to accommodate academic calendars.11 
The  conference  involves  3  days  of  presentations,  a  half-day  for  grant  approvals,  and  a 
marketplace, for 4 days total (para. 13). The 3-day conference will include six plenary sessions 
as  well  as  concurrent  sessions  on  microfinance,  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises, 
conditional cash transfers, work with the ultra-poor, and information dissemination.12 Gender-
disaggregated  data,  analysis,  and  results  will  be  actively  sought  and  incorporated  in  all 
presentations if possible. Intended participants include academics, presenters, development 
partners, regulators, and policy makers in the five topic areas. Two lunch sessions will be 
provided  for  academics  to  discuss  technical  RCT  issues.  All  presented  papers  will  have 
commenters. The conference proceedings will be provided on the ADB website as a knowledge 
product; all other material publication rights will rest with the presenters.  
 
13.  The competitive innovation evaluation grants will be transparently allocated to rigorous, 
innovative research projects with policy relevance to the DMCs. Two field implementation grants 
for $100,000 each to help implement impact evaluations and for four start-up grants of $25,000 
to design suitable impact evaluation proposals for key projects will be awarded, with more funds 
possible from  pending collaboration  arrangements.13 The  process, to  be  undertaken for  4 
months preceding the conference, will involve (i) development and confirmation of the criteria 
and panels, (ii) distribution of a request for proposals, (iii) initial screening, (iv) peer review, (v) 
panel review, (vi) selection of grantees, (vii) notification and disbursement, and (viii) reporting on 
progress  and  results.  ADB  will  approve  the  process  and  all  grants.  The  grants  will  be 
announced at the end of the international conference, along with a marketplace allowing new 
ideas to emerge and be discussed.  Grants will be implemented over the final two and a half 
years of the TA, with researchers and practitioners engaging with DMC officials on the process 
and results as well as policy implications. General write-ups of the results will be provided for 
knowledge sharing on the ADB website; all other publication rights will rest with the grantees. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA cost is estimated at $950,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The TA will cover training and 
conference costs, remuneration, travel and per diem, and miscellaneous expenses. Proceeds of 
the TA will be disbursed in accordance with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time.)  The cost estimates are in Appendix 2.  
 
                                                
11  The conference venue has not yet been established, as the financiers may provide additional resources based on 
the location; Beijing, Paris, Manila, Seoul, and Sydney are being considered. The Organization for Economic 
Cooperation and Development has been approached regarding donation of conference facilities and translation in 
their Paris location. The location will be finalized by the end of February 2012 and final number of participants will 
be defined at that time, based on total available resources, with a minimum of 100 and a maximum of 450. 
12 An indicative list is included in Appendix 3.  
13 The amount allocated to the grants as pilot testing normally should not exceed 30%.  In this case the total is 31.5% 
and is justified by the nature of the R-CDTA to encourage improved evaluation through demonstration effects.

5 
15.  Since October 2010, ADB has been actively discussing collaboration arrangements with 
the Inter-American Development Bank for significant additional participation of their developing 
country officials in the training and conference, and for separate funds to be awarded to grantee 
applicants for evaluation activities in their developing member countries.  Citi Foundation and 
the Islamic Development Bank stated that they were considering additional funds for the same 
purpose,  and  the  African  Development  Bank  has  been  approached  for  the  same  type  of 
engagement. Such additional funds would be separately managed. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The  TA  will  begin  on  15  January  2012  and  end  on  31  May  2015.  The  41-month 
implementation is needed for completion of the innovation evaluation grants in the DMCs. ADB 
will  be  the  executing  agency.  The  Public  Management,  Financial  Sector,  and  Regional 
Cooperation  Division  of  the  East  Asia  Department  in collaboration  with IED’s  Independent 
Evaluation Division 2 will implement the TA. The assignments will be split between the co-team 
leaders. The IED officer will guide the training course development and delivery, and the non-
ADB financed grants selection implementation; while the East Asia Department officer will 
oversee work with parallel cofinanciers, conference setup, and ADB-related grants selection and 
implementation. The co-team leaders will work together to manage these and all other matters, 
and with the consultant will to help ameliorate the risk that DMCs do not use the new evaluation 
technologies.  
 
17.  One international consultant will be recruited for 8 person-months, intermittent, by single-
source selection from the Financial Access Initiative14 through submission of proposal of the 
individual by the Innovations for Poverty Action. The consultant will manage all arrangements 
for the training development and delivery, conference setup, management and logistics, grants 
competition,  and general grants  implementation  oversight. The  Financial  Access  Initiative’s 
Innovations for Poverty Action established and ran the first conference in 2010, administers a 
Gates Fund grant for evaluation grants, and has established a unique and extensive worldwide 
network of evaluation researchers. It has a unique capability to provide a qualified research 
professional for this task. ADB will engage the consultant in accordance with the Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Any procurement under the TA, 
including  innovation  evaluation  grants,  will  be  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
18.  The knowledge products include the training e-learning tool, conference proceedings, 
grant methodology, and grant results. ADB will provide all of these on its website and through 
the Financial Access Initiative networks. In addition, both IED and East Asia Department will 
share the materials with officials in the DMCs and encourage full participation in all events.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $950,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening Evaluation of Poverty Reduction Innovations, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board. 
                                                
14 The initiative is housed at the Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University. It is led by 
Jonathan Morduch, managing director (New York University); Dean Karlan, director (Yale University); and Sendhil 
Mullainathan, director (Harvard University). http://financialaccess.org/about/fai

Appendix 4  11 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR THE CONSULTANT 
 
1.  The  conference,  training,  and  grant  coordinator  will  be  an  international  consultant 
(engaged for 8 person-months intermittent). The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will select and 
engage the coordinator in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The consultant will be selected on a single-source selection basis 
through  the  Financial  Access  Initiative  partner,  Innovations  in  Poverty  Action,  to  manage 
arrangements for the training, conference, and grants competition. Innovations in Poverty Action 
qualifies for single-source selection provision of the consultant as it (i) has unique qualifications 
that represent a natural continuation of previous work carried out by the firm, following the first 
international conference in 2010 with the evaluation grants competition; (ii) can implement small 
 
assignments such as this, and (iii) has experience of exceptional worth for the assignment. 
 
2.  The  coordinator  (i)  should  have  sufficient  tertiary  qualifications,  expertise,  and 
experience  in  impact  evaluation  of  public  interventions  and  a  good  understanding  of  the 
evaluation issues in financial inclusion and poverty reduction in developing countries; and (ii) 
must have solid knowledge of ongoing activities in this field worldwide, particularly in key 
technical areas identified for the training and conference. Prior work on the 2010 conference is 
important, as is work in the field and grant-making processes.  
 
3.  The coordinator will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  With the ADB team, determine training demand metrics and identify training 
facilitators; 
(ii)  Develop  training  program  and  materials,  and  conduct  3-day  training  for 
developing  member  country  (DMC)  policy  makers  and  researchers  in  new 
methods of impact evaluation, including an introduction to randomized control 
trials  and  alternatives,  inclusive  of  pre  and  post  conference  tests  of  this 
knowledge;  
(iii)  Recruit training facilitators and a logistics team to manage the training; 
(iv)  Identify and invite training participants (approximately 30) from DMCs, including 
policy makers, researchers, and development practitioners; 
(v)  Develop an e-learning tool based on the training course and set up for the ADB 
website as a knowledge product; 
(vi)  Submit to ADB all training materials and videotape at training completion; 
(vii)  Establish  the  conference  approach  and  flow,  ensure  high  international 
participation and presentations of the latest results in impact evaluation from the 
field, and manage the logistics firm for the conference and trouble-shooting;  
(viii)  Locate and ensure participation of key worldwide researchers and implementers 
with new results in impact evaluations that are relevant to participants; 
(ix)  Invite and engage policy makers and researchers from ADB DMCs, along with 
other suitable participants for the conference, with support from ADB and other 
financiers as appropriate; 
(x)  Recruit a logistics team to manage the conference on site; 
(xi)  Arrange  and  manage  the  conference  meetings  and  schedule  for  maximum 
learning  and  engagement;  complete  proceedings  within  2  weeks  of  the 
conference to be placed on the ADB website as a knowledge product;  
(xii)  Help establish and manage appropriate systems for application, review, scoring, 
and selection and awarding of large and small grants, based on available funds;

12  Appendix 4 
 
 
(xiii)  Establish  and  manage  reporting  systems  for  grantees  and  handover  when 
appropriate, and ensure the funds are managed in accordance with ADB rules as 
per ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time); 
(xiv)  Contribute to summaries of results of grants at completion to be provided as 
knowledge products online; and  
(xv)  Provide all financial and other output reports in high quality as per the design and 
monitoring framework for the technical assistance.
